metadata.synopsis: Roscoe Rules (Tim McIntire) is exactly the kind of cop you don't want on the job. When he's not getting drunk after hours, he is insulting the citizens he supposedly serves. And his cop buddies are no better, from the always-angry Sam (Don Stroud) to the geeky Harold (James Woods), who constantly makes questionable busts of prostitutes. When a member of the group mistakenly shoots a gay man in a park while the gang is out carousing, everyone closes ranks to cover up the crime.

reviews: I don't know how Aldrich, a usually good director who can go off from time to time, can be responsible for this.
What is more interesting about this singular and violent film is its critique -- both cheerful and fierce -- of the police. [Full Review in Spanish]
The actors are all fine talents who probably thought they'd be making the novel; poor idealistic dreamers. Don't they know what Hollywood does to good books?
The Choirboys takes a fairly obnoxious place among a burgeoning genre of Hollywood films determined to revel in raunchiness.
This is not one of Aldrich's better films.
A chaotic and fairly unlikable adaptation.
